div.p:
Dearest mother
I left off I believe where Fanny
was about to give a dinner and
I go on with -
It was a most agreeable dinner
in the first place in my opinion
forwhom it was most intended and
next in the opinions of all the
guests who evidently in and
proved with out a doubt by their
laughing talking and eating
their fill were jointly and severally
pleased and happily satisfied

The Convives were D.r Lushington
primo - M r .Andrews - secundo -
M r. M c .Intosh (Sir James' son) tertio
(The males being always put first in play bill)
Females
Miss Carr- & M rs Beaufort- who kindly
came to supply the place of Mrs. Andrews
who at the last sent a regret- in bed headache

So you see Miss Carr was the only
strange lady - But Honora supplied
the place of M rs .Andrews to perfection,
Well dressed in pretty flowered cap &
nice curled hair looking & talking
highbred beside M r .Andrews who
took herdown & Lestock who liked to
have her beside him -- D r .Lushington
beside F M W
Fanny -- proper & very agreeable
carving remarkably well
with her & without her talking away
not a word of Politics or Religion & then
he is the most entertaining & agreeable
- and he has left off being in facti-
-tious factitious
enthusiasm about every
thing & her natural high spirits
(poor man) have been lowered
to sympathy - point or to my sympa-
-thising sympathising
possibility - He raised the
hearts laugh frequently & the
heads by anecdotes & fresh
not old faded London diner out
bon mots and anecdotes &
facts if not secret worth knowing
- all with the connivance &
assistance of M r .Andrews who
(pray tell Harriet Butler )
I think a remarkably agreeable
gentlemanly gentleman
They played into each others hands
and mine delightfully and Frances ,
and Honoras & the ball came to every
body's hands pat - in turn
the Ball - did I say - Boomarang I had
better have said - for it came back
always nicely to the thrower

a more agreeable conversation dinner
I never heard - nor a better more cooked well
elegant proportioned & well served dinner I never
saw - eat or saw eaten

Coffee time & evening and all to
match - ending past eleven without
anybody knowing how

D r . Lushington as I have since learned from
Miss Carr reiterated in the carriage as they
went home "What a merry pleasant dinner
we had !"- But what is much more to
my mind Lestock enjoyed it & joined
in at the time (excellent wines too not
throw away on Lushington
and afterward Lestocksaid to Fanny
how much he had been pleased
with it all - How well he thought it
went off - and especially how agree
-able he thought Dr .L - Now this
was particularly pleasing both to
Fanny & to me - for she had asked
Lushington for me ( to save my going
to dine with them ) and tho' Lestock
kindly gave-in to it, it was rather
a contre coeur; as Lushington had
not won her heart formerly - being a desper
ate desperate
Whig as he is ! How should he?-

But having kept clear of politics &c
no man could be as Lestock him
-self himself
said more agreeable - QED-
and a delightful QED to me
for I do hate to bore Lestock with
the old lioness's worshippers all coming
to feed, or be fed; Some of them Roaring-lions
themselves tobystanding on their hind
legs opposite to Lestocks silent face -
- a face! -enough (as I should feel)
to turn any living lion rampant = roaring
into a lion couchant = mute, - on
the spot -

You see I am happy & in
good spirits - and you feel without
my saying it (but I will say it
nevertheless ) that Fanny is not the
worse in the least any way for
this dinner - Whether she is the
different from what I last saw what
suited her former figure that
altogether it made me feel the
lapse of the ten years since we had met
a rich stand an-endwatered silk
of amber color
by candle light
perhaps by day light golden yellow
such as Rosa & Francis patronise
Double Ruffles of light lace & light
sleeves like old Vandyke picture

Quick from Emmas most
politely kind welcome I turned to
look for M rs. Sneyd who was making
her way between Wall flowers &
Quadrille circles up to the us -
( She too was so changed that I
could not at all have known
her - grown downwards - and
huddled up with black satin
shawl hiding neck & pinned
unmercifully across whole figure
hiding all outline of limb & form
and surmounted by the likeness of a little
old womans morning cape of blonde
it might be but dowged & not in
its first freshness it looked to me
- and the whole face so squeezed
together & brow & mouth so wrinkled
& crinkled I could not concieve it
to be in the once young & radiant not the afterwards fashionable
well set up M rs Sneyd of Byrkley Lodge
however - When she came so near
that I could see her countenance
I recognised the unchanged
expression of cheerful, polite bene
volence benvolence
- As she greeted me &
thanked
that last sentence about Dr
Ashburner was quite a
as proved by his heads appearing
coming in at the door behind
the red skreen at the very instant
I came to the last words of last page

He felt her pulse & finds it only
eighty four - & is well satisfied
and thats enough -

He brought with him a Mr .
Kennion a brother of Lord Kennions
one of the best of the jovial class of London
diners, a breakfaster-out - He
has been interrupting me full hour yet in spite
of that entertaining me unto the last
gasp - The last thing he told I
give as a specimen - a saying
of Missrs Brooke's sister of Baron Garrow

The Baron notwithstanding his
bullying manner as a lawyer in court
was a man easily swayed in private
and one of those who always are in-
fluenced influenced
by the last thing said & the
last person who is in their company
- all which ideas M rs. Brooke compressed into
" With my brother always"Presence is power"

But now I must quit your
presence & go to dress to go to M rs Sneyd
- Honora is to call for me at half
after
half part seven - Half past 6 now
and I have to dress & dine

Goodbye - It is snowing as
hard as it can - But snow or not snow
Go we must - we must go
It is astonishing how soon and
London musts - and must goes
the human heart hardens towards
horses and men!- And even
my own in one short month begins
I feel to ossify apace

I must go - But
still I am heartily glad Fannys
John is not to go with us
Honoras man is to go and
I don't care for him - he is not
one of our ownselves.- And
as to horses - by the job - who
cares for job horses!- they are
scarcely animals only moving
machines - and steam will
soon take their hay & oats out
of their mouths
div.closer:
yours humanely &
Emily B is delighted
to go to this little
dance -
Maria Edgeworth
